text: A DARK FIGURE in a tattered trench coat tumbles onto the pavement, hands out to slow the impact. A beat then slowl he climbs to his feet, recovering from what seems to have been quite a fall. He has chiseled features, shaved head, deep-set eyes. Looks like he's been through one hell of a fight. His name, we will come to know, is MICHAEL. He quickly checks out his surroundings, nothing but brick walls above him. Where'd this guy jump from? A RUMBLE of thunder...then RAIN starts to hammer down. to motivate him. Michael pulls his overcoat tight around his body and dash toward the mouth of the alley. He reaches the STREET just time to see a FLEET OF POLICE CARS tearing around the cor SIRENS WAILING, heading this way. He reels back into the alley way, ducks down behind a tra dumpster, as the BLUE AND RED LIGHTS of the POLICE CARS w past. Michael waits for the lights to disappear, then he pulls MASSIVE ORNATE KNIFE from his jacket. Considers it grimly Runs his finger along its edge. Blood beads up. Razor sharp. Michael begins to peel off his overcoat, revealing his ba chest underneath...and skin literally covered with DARK TATOOS. Hard to see what they are in this light. As his coat falls to the ground, we DRIFT over to the BRI WALL behind him where we see MICHAEL'S SHADOW crouch over and then...

head_text.subj: ...TWO LARGE SHAPES UNFOLD FROM HIS BACK, STRETCHING UP I
WHAT ARE UNMISTAKABLY...THE SHADOW OF WINGS.

text: The RAIN POUNDS harder, as if punishment from the heavens The glint of the KNIFE coming down fast. A HORRENDOUS SOUND OF FLESH TEARING AWAY FROM BONE... ...THE BLOODY KNIFE CLATTERING TO THE PAVEMENT...

head_text.subj: ...FOLLOWED BY MICHAEL'S UNGODLY SCREAM RISING UP FROM TH

text: ALLEY WAY. And then SILENCE...

head_text.subj: THE GUTTER, AS BLOOD BEGINS TO FLOW FREELY, MIXI

text: Michael, face tight with pain, trench coat back on, steps of the alley, stares with determination at a dark storefr across the street.
Cavernous. A Costco for survivalists.    Quiet except for sound of RAIN, then... SMASH! Michael drops down through one of the skylights in shower of glass.

Michael bursts in. Tosses a first-aid kit into the sink. His trench coat falls to the floor and here in the fluorescent light, we get a better look at him. His thin but stunningly well muscled body is TATTOOED shoulder to ankle with INTRICATE WRITING. The man's flesh a living book. But the writing is in no language we recognize. He turns his back to the mirror, revealing two HORRIFICAL OPEN WOUNDS running down between both shoulder blades. FRESH. BLOODY. He threads a needle not with thread, but with FISHING WIR and begins to STITCH the wounds closed. BLOOD POOLS on th cement floor around his feet.

Trench coat and a shirt back on, Michael races along the ENDLESS RACKS OF GUNS, searching for just the right weapo his every movement precise, as if he's trained his whole for this. Weapon after ferocious weapon gets tossed into rifle bags Whatever this guy's preparing for, it's big. Rifle bags filled, Michael heads for the exit.   Stops co The place is locked up tight.   Metal gate over the front doors, bars over the windows.   How the hell's he going t out of here?

Two COPS, world weary, cruise through downtown. That's BURTON behind the wheel, ESTEVEZ riding shotgun. The POLICE RADIO is ABUZZ WITH ACTIVITY.      Busy night. Burton stares out at the city's rain soaked denizens with deep hatred, the shadows looming in doorways, the streetwalkers.
Goddamn' animals. Nights like this I wish I could take a match to this city just so I could watch all these motherfuckers burn.
(LAUGHS) A good ol' boy barbecue, huh?
Burton doesn't even smile.       He's dead fucking seriou
A fresh start. That's what this place needs.
He holds his finger up like a pistol. Aims it at the peop they pass, picking them off one by one.
Pow!   Pow!     Pow!
Now Burton laughs, a dark, mean laugh.      Estevez eyes partner, wary.
Jesus... You know Burton, I'm so happy we get to share beautiful moments like this. They really brighten my da--
KABOOM! Through the WINDSHIELD, we see a storefront EXPLO just ahead, raining fiery debris onto the squad car. Burton slams on the breaks and the cops look up just in t to see...
Michael, bulging rifle bags in each hand, stepping brazen out of the GAPING HOLE he's blown in the front of the sto
Freeze!
Estevez and Burton are already out of the squad car, crouching behind the open doors, GUNS trained on Michael.
Drop the bags! Hands on your head!

In the distance, the POP-POP of GUNFIRE. The POLICE RADIO CRACKLES with URGENT CHATTER. MANY VOICES TALKING AT ONCE "Shots fired...Code Three...Officer down!" The cops shift about nervously, trying to stay focused.
(sensing their unease:) It's starting. There isn't much time.
The cops shoot a quick, anxious glance at each other -- " the hell?" -- then they turn back to Michael.
Shut the fuck up and drop the bags now!
Michael lets the gun bags hit the ground.
Hands on your head!    On your head!
Michael slowly places his palms on his skull.
Turn around! Turn the fuck around!

Michael slowly turns around.    Calm. Estevez rushes in to restrain Michael, grabbing his wrist FINGERS TIGHTENING. Michael closes his eyes, a terrible decision made. And that's when he moves, a fucking blur! In an instant Michael's broken the cop's arm, spinning hi helplessly around, turning him into a human shield. Now i Michael who's in charge, gun to Estevez's head, facing of with Burton. Burton struggles to find a shot, can't.
Let `em go!
Take the shot, Burton!
I said let `em fuckin' g-g-g-g--
Suddenly Burton starts to SHAKE, the words stuck in his throat like a skipping record.
Burton!?

THE STREET LAMPS BEGIN TO FLICKER AND STROBE, adding to t confusion. Burton squeezes his eyes shut in pain, his WHOLE BODY QUAKING, heels CLICKING the pavement, as if some massive pressure were building inside him. And with the horrific sound of CRACKING BONES, BURTON'S M
His eyes SNAP OPEN, focused, the force inside him now ful in control. Burton looks at Michael with calm recognition, his voice GUTTURAL..INHUMAN. A man possessed.
What are you doing, Michael?   These weren't your orders.
Estevez looks at his partner with confusion.
What did you say?
Michael, however, seems to know exactly who he's talking
I'm following my own orders now.
Then you will die along with the child.
Burton, you fuckin' know this guy?!

BLAM! Burton shoots his partner in the head. Estevez drop leaving Michael without cover. Burton re-aims, but Michae faster, already FIRING back. Bullets rip up the concrete. SMASH!   The squad car windo SHATTERS, Burton's chest EXPLODING!

And down he GOES, leaving Michael the only one left stand Smoke rising from his gun. With soldier-like efficiency, Michael picks up the rifle and begins to load them into the trunk of the squad car. He gets in the car and FLOORS IT, ROARING AWAY, as the

head_text.subj: FLICKERING STREET LAMPS FINALLY GO OUT IN RAPID SUCCESSIO

text: wave chasing him, PLUNGING THE ENTIRE CITY INTO DARKNESS.
Bolts awake.   Breathing hard.   Covered with sweat.
Jeep switches on a lamp, illuminating this incredibly cra bedroom. Not much larger than the bed itself. He's got shaggy hair, a sensitive face, clearly not big on sunligh

A couple of ancient SILVERSTREAM TRAILERS are bathed in t eerie blue light of night's final moments. It looks like trailers haven't moved from this patch of barren ground i decades. A single strand of colored Christmas lights dot trailers roof lines, marking the season. One of the trailer doors CREAKS open and Jeep steps weari out into the cool western morning. Home. Nothing but desert for miles in all directions, save for two lane HIGHWAY and a weather beaten TRUCK STOP DINER th Jeep and his father will open for business in a few hours Jeep gazes up to the diner's slanted roof where a large s glows like a beacon in the darkness:
A beat as Jeep contemplates the sign.
You okay, Jeep?
Jeep turns to see CHARLIE, a very pregnant girl of about twenty, standing in the trailer doorway, rubbing the slee from her eyes. Even with the trailer-trash veneer, she's strikingly beautiful.
Sorry to wake you, Charlie.
(stepping out of the trailer, hands on her
Wasn't you. He's been kickin' up a storm all night. Must know somethin' I don't.
She approaches Jeep.   Sees the strain in his eyes.
Another bad dream?
He struggles for a moment, nods.
It's just stress, Jeep, that's all. You do too much worryin'. About this place. About your dad. (BEAT) About me...
A glimmer of a smile crosses Jeep's face.
You're the only thing I like worrying about.
See what I mean? You're worried about a girl eight months pregnant and it isn't even your baby. Now that's enough to give anybody nightmares.
Jeep turns away, dejected.
Go ahead, make fun of me. Everybody else does.

(turns him back around) C'mon, I was only kiddin'. You know how much I appreciate everything you and Bob are doing for me, but a month from now, this baby'll have a new family and I'll have to start thinkin' about what the hell I'm doin' with my life.
This is not news Jeep wants to hear.
So you're still going through with it...?
Jeep, I'm not ready to be a mama. Christ, I can barely take care of myself as it is.
I could help you. We could do it together, you know? I want to.
Charlie smiles sadly at him, touched by his sweetness, bu this just isn't where she's at.
You gotta stop carryin' the weight of the world on your shoulders.
Jeep nods, tries to hide the fact that he's dying inside.
(rubbing her arms) Now can we go back in? I'm freezing my ass off out here.
Go on.   I'll be right there.

Charlie kisses him on the cheek and heads back to the trailer. He watches her, longing in his eyes. With the clank of the door, she's gone. And over Jeep's troubled look, the perennial holiday chee FRANK CAPRA'S "IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE" MIXES up.
I don't know whether I like it very much being seen around with an angel without any wings.

head_text.subj: IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE PLAYING ON A CRUMMY TV

text: Jimmy Stewart as George Bailey has just met Clarence, his guardian angel-in-training. The signal ROLLS and SNOWS in and out. We hear a WHACK, which causes the image to momentarily improve and then slowly roll back the other w
Oh, I've got to earn them and you'll help me, won't you?

BOB HANSEN (late 40's), owner and proprietor of this fine roadside establishment, attempts to fix the old TV hangin the corner above the counter by banging the shit out it. The restaurant itself has the kind of grungy diner charm you'd hope to find in a place last renovated in 1963. An plastic Christmas tree strung with flickering lights and tinsel occupies a lonely corner. Next to that, a faded diorama of the NATIVITY SCENE. The kind you might order o the Shopping Network. Bob considers the TV with a frown. He deftly rolls an ENGRAVED SILVER ZIPPO back and forth over the nicotine stained fingers of his right hand. Must be a nervous habi You can tell just by looking at the man that he's a beer drinker. Behind the counter, a black man named PERCY WALKER (60's) cooking up a storm on the grill with spectacular one-hand dexterity. You do get pretty good at this sort of thing w your other hand has long been replaced by a METAL HOOK. dog tags around his neck tell the story. His white cook's hat has been temporarily replaced by a red Santa hat.
Lord as my witness, Bob, one of these days that thing's gonna hit you back.
Whaddya talkin' about, Percy? We got a special relationship here.
Yeah, they got names for that kind a relationship.

The JUKEBOX on the other side of the diner starts up with MERLE HAGGARD tune "I'M A LONESOME FUGITIVE". A stunning looking sixteen-year-old GIRL with dyed-black and a piercing or three, is leaning seductively over the jukebox, swaying gently to the music. The headband doubli as her mini-skirt reveals her knock-out figure in a way t really doesn't leave much up to the imagination. She's a billboard of rebellion.
It's disgusting.
You're right. It is disgusting.
Watching the scintillating action from a booth across the diner is a conservatively dressed SUBURBAN COUPLE. SANDRA and HOWARD ANDERSON. Fish out of water.
Really, how can she go out in public wearing that?
I don't know. Why don't we just ask her?
Howard, don't. You'll embarrass me.
(shouting across the
Audrey, honey? Your mother was wondering if you got dressed this morning with the specific intention of showing your ass off to the entire world?
The girl who we now know as AUDREY ANDERSON turns to Howa with a caustic smile.
Yeah, that's cuz I woke up hoping to get double teamed by a couple of meth head truckers in the bathroom of some desert shithole. (BEAT) Good thing we stopped here.
And with that she turns back to the jukebox. Percy watche the exchange discreetly from behind the counter. Loving i Howard turns back to his wife.   Rigid smile.
I feel satisfied with that answer. I really do.
Sandra buries her face in her hands.
I'm being punished for something, I know it.
Across the diner, Audrey goes back to swaying dreamily to music, which is suddenly overtaken by BASS BUMPIN' HIP-HO

head_text.subj: DRIFTING OVER A VAST EXPANSE OF WESTERN DESERT

text: The noontime sun bakes the strip of highway slicing throu this barren country. A BLACK CADILLAC ESCALADE blazes a path.   HEAVY BEATS th from within.
The stereo in this rig could shake mountains. KYLE WILLIA (late 20's) handsome as hell, thug style. A straight up b boy. He passes a weathered road sign:
Kyle's expression says this is not good news. He grabs his cell phone off the passenger seat.   No sign
Shit...
He spots the truck stop diner just up the road ahead...

The Escalade pulls off the highway and rolls to a stop at lonely row of old gas pumps. Kyle gets out and surveys the scenery with dismay. Now in the daytime we see this is truly a place time forgot. Attached to the diner is a MECHANIC'S BAY. Grease stains rusty car parts litter the ground. Behind the place is th SILVERSTREAM TRAILER we saw Jeep step out of earlier. The only thing here that looks fairly new is the UHAUL TR parked in front of the garage with its hood up. Kyle grabs a crumpled hand drawn map from the front seat flattens it out on the roof of the car. He spins it aroun Which way is north?
Darren, your fuckin' directions suck, man.

He checks his cell phone again. No chance of a signal way out here. So he shuffles around to the side of the diner search of a pay phone. The good news is that he finds one.   The bad news is tha it's been broken for ten years. Leaning next to the broken phone, however, is Charlie wea a shabby, faded WAITRESS uniform stretched tight around h very pregnant belly. Adding to her perfect mother-to-be l is that cigarette dangling from her lips. The plastic nam tag pinned to her chest says "CHARLIE".
Hey...
She eyes him, mildly intrigued, takes a drag.
You know that shit right there ain't good for the baby.
She lets out a long slow exhale.
Guess I should think `bout quittin' then.
Now hold on, girl, let me bum one before you do.
You can buy a whole pack inside.
Tell ya what. You let me have one of yours, and I'll give you two from the new pack you're gonna sell me.
She considers him for a moment, then pulls out a cigarett Lights it off the end of hers then hands it to him. Kyle takes a drag, pulls out his crumpled map.
Am I in the right place?
(peers at the map) Only if nowhere's right, `cause that's where you are.
Sonuvabitch. There another phone around here? You know, one that works?
Bob'll probably let you use the diner phone if you ask him real nice...And pay `im somethin'.
I can handle that.   You got pancakes here?
Yeah, we got a buttermilk stack for three seventy-five. We also got french toast for four dollars if you're into that. I personally like the pancakes though.
You okay, Charlie?
They both turn to see Jeep behind the diner, wearing mechanic's coveralls and holding a DUSTY OLD CRIB. Charli quickly hides her cigarette behind her back. Busted.
Yeah, I'm okay. This guy's just lost.
Jeep nods, uncertain, eyes Kyle another moment, then he shuffles along out of sight. Charlie brings the cigarette back up to her lips. An awkward beat.
Three seventy-five, huh?

The DOOR JINGLES.   Charlie and Kyle enter. Audrey's eyes light up when she sees Kyle. He notices her well. How couldn't he? She's directing every ounce of sex appeal she has in his direction. Her parents, on the other hand, shoot a look of utter fea Kyle's direction, as if he personified their worst suburb nightmare. Charlie heads to the register. Digs out a fresh pack of smokes from underneath the counter.
I hope Salem Lights are okay, `cause that's all we got left.
If I can smoke `em, I'll take `em.
Where ya been, Charlie?
Bob steps off the chair.
This ain't a resort you know.    I got orders stacking up here.
In truth there aren't any orders stacking up, but it certainly makes Bob feel better to say it.
(sees the two cigarettes Kyle's handing her) You best not be smokin' again.    Not in your condition.
(gestures to the diner) Bob, do you see where am I right now? Can my condition really get any worse? `Sides, you ain't one to talk.
What?   I quit two years ago.
Yeah, so why you still carryin' that fancy lighter `round for?
It was a gift from my ex-wife, alright? I'm sentimental. I don't wanna forget how much I hate her guts.
Hey man?
Bob turns to Kyle.   Doesn't like what he sees.
Can I use your phone? My cell doesn't get a signal out here and the pay phone outside is busted.
Bob is about to respond when:
Excuse me...?
Howard approaches, oblivious to the conversation he's interrupting.
Any news about when our truck might be fixed? You said your boy would have us on the road two hours ago. The rate we're going, we'll be lucky to make it to Scottsdale by Christmas.
Bob's expression darkens at this news.
Goddamn it. Where the hell is Jeep?
A cloth wipes away the dirt, revealing the partial image an ANGEL carved into the surface.
Jeep is carefully cleaning the old wooden crib on a workbench. There's an unsettling intensity in his eyes, a if fear itself were driving him.
Hey, Leonardo...!
Jeep freezes, knows he's in trouble He reluctantly turns see his father standing next to the Anderson's broken-dow Uhual.
The fact that this truck's hood's up mean anything to you?
Jeep stares at the ground.   Couldn't be anymore uncomfortable.
Yeah...
(approaches, peering past him to the crib)
BOB (cont'd) Whaddya workin' on that's so goddamn important you're not doin' your job?
Nothin'...
Jeep tries feebly to block his path, fails. Bob looks down at the crib with dismay.
Found it under a bunch of stuff in the storage shed. I know you never like to throw anything away...
Bob considers him, softens.
Whaddya doin'?
What...?
Jeep, I like Charlie. I do. And I think it's real good of you to lend her a helping hand, but she is not your responsibility.
(heard this before, pushes past him) Oh whatever, leave me alone.
Don't walk away from me while I'm talkin' to you!
Jeep walks out toward the gas pumps, but Bob's right alongside him, not giving up.
How long you gonna follow her around like a puppy dog? Cleanin' up the messes she makes while she steps out with every guy around here other than you?!
Jeep stiffens.   Turns to his father:
Don't say that about her!     She's not like that!
Bob gives Jeep a hard stare.    Yeah, she is.
You really think she's gonna stick around here after that baby's born and off her hands?
Jeeps shakes his head, burns.
Look, I know it doesn't make any sense to you, but it's just something I have to do.
Bob sighs, feels for his boy.

(points up at the PARADISE FALLS sign) See that up there? Your mother thought I was crazy for wanting to buy this place, middle of nowhere...But I just knew this was what I was supposed to do. Told your mom, "just wait." Told her when they finally ran the freeway through here like they were plannin' on, this place would be like Grand Central Station. (BEAT) But I was wrong. The freeway never came and now the only people who ever stop here are the ones who are lost. (BEAT) And your mom? Well she got tired of waitin'.
C'mon Dad. You can't blame yourself for what she did--

Yeah, I can. And I'm sayin' you're about to make the same damn mistake I made, believing in something that's never gonna happen...Or someone. (BEAT) It's time for you to move on from this place, Jeep. I don't wanna see you wake up one morning old and pissed off, realizing you're lost just like everybody else who stops here.
Jeep looks up at his father, his words hanging heavily. tough pill to swallow.
Now get to work on that truck. I wanna have these people on the road by nightfall.

Bob walks back into the diner. Jeep is about to turn back to the garage when he notices something off in the distance. Ominous DARK CLOUDS line the horizon to the south like a living wall. He shifts his gaze up the highway to the nor Same thing. DARK CLOUDS are pushing their way over the distant mountains. A storm is coming.
Bob reenters the diner to find Kyle sitting at the counte digging into a plate of banana pancakes. Kyle is about to address him again, when something else steals Bob's attention.
(holding up a silencing
Yeah, wait a minute.
The TV has gone on the fritz again.   Only now the image mostly snow. Bob climbs back onto the chair.   Faces the TV.
What's wrong with you today?
The image flickers but doesn't improve.
I told you to get the satellite TV. But you don't wanna listen.
What the hell do I need that crap for?
History Channel, man!
I got all the history I can take.
That's for sure.
What's your problem now?
Where do I start?
You know this was the top-of-the- line model when I bought it.
Yeah, in the Fifties.
You shouldn't be watchin' anyways. (rubs his hands together) Okay, baby, this is gonna do it.

Bob gives the TV one final wallop -- WHACK! And the picture snaps into FOCUS.    Only it isn't the pi he was expecting. The STARK GRAPHIC OF THE EMERGENCY BROADCASTING SYSTEM an its accompanying HOLLOW TONE fill the diner. Everybody in the place stops and turns to the TV.
See?   Clear as day.
Nice work, Bob. What the hell's that?
It's just one of those test things.
That'd be true, except for the words at the bottom of the screen, which read:
Bob switches the channels.    All the same.
Don't look like a test.
Bob steps off the chair and backs slowly away from the TV if a little distance will bring some clarity. He bumps in Kyle.
Yo, am I the Invisible motherfuckin' Man here?    Do you have a phone or not?
Kyle peels a five dollar bill off a serious WAD OF CASH. That gets Bob's attention. Bob snaps the money out of his hand.
In the back past the kitchen.   Make it fast.
Kyle hustles passed Percy. Charlie is standing by the Anderson's table, clearing dis Everybody's eyes are locked on the TV.
If there's a real emergency aren't they supposed to give us some information about what to do?
I'm sure it's a mistake.
Hey, Percy, give that old radio of yours a shot. Maybe they got some news about the TV.

Percy grabs an old battery powered radio off a kitchen sh Switches it on. STATIC.   He spins the dial until he reaches a clear sign The same HOLLOW TONE of Emergency Broadcasting.   Station after station the same thing. The diner is overwhelmed by a chilling chorus of HOLLOW TONES. Everyone goes very still.
Let me talk to him...
Kyle sits at a messy desk in this dark, wood paneled back office, phone to his ear.

(on phone) Cuz a father should be able to talk to his son, that's why. Now put `im on the phone. (a beat then a smile) Is that my little man...? Yeah, well I'm working hard, so that I can be with you. You bein' good? (strange STATIC can be
Wait... You're breakin' up. Hello...? (hangs up in frustration) Shit!
Kyle stews a beat, then picks up the phone to redial. Frowns. No dial tone.
What the hell...
He keeps trying.    Nothing.
Maybe there was an earthquake?
Everyone is looking at Howard.
They keep sayin' we're overdue for a big one.
Lot a folks could be hurt.
Not if it was centered in the desert.
Exactly.    Could be nothing to worry about.
So then why's the TV out?
Maybe it just hit the relay stations. Aren't those usually in remote areas?
Yeah, `cause of the radiation they give off.
There ain't no radiation comin' from those things. Plus that don't explain the radio being out too. Some of those stations broadcast over hundreds of miles. Any quake that big and we would a felt it.
Percy's right. I didn't feel nothing.
Maybe it's a terrorist attack or something...?
(covers her mouth) Oh god...
Everyone considers that grimly, then:
Well, for cryin' out loud. There's no use in speculating. I'll just call my brother up in Needles. He must a heard something.
I don't think so.
Kyle has reappeared in the diner.
Whaddya talkin' about?
Phone's dead. Just tried to make a call.
You're shittin' me.
Kyle shakes his head, sits down at the counter.
Oh, this is just great.
Relax, Mrs. Anderson. Nothing to get excited about. Probably just working on the lines.
BOB (cont'd) Sides, I'm sure Jeep'll have your truck fixed up quick as can be, and then you'll be on your way.
Jeep is buried under the Uhaul's hood, working at somethi with a socket wrench. It's not going well.
Damn it!

He pulls himself up. Grease covers his face and hands. sound of a CAR APPROACHING catches his attention. He watches as a beat up EIGHTIES CUTLASS SUPREME pulls of the highway and rolls to a stop at the pumps. It's a myst how anyone could see through the LAYER OF DUST on that windshield. After a moment the car door pops open and the LEGS OF AN ELDERLY WOMAN swing down to the ground, followed by the m frame and wheels of a walker. The LITTLE OLD LADY gets out of the car, steadies herself the walker, and then slowly makes her way toward the dine with the rickety frailness of an old turtle. Jeep watches her disappear inside. He then looks toward the horizon again.   The WALL OF DAR CLOUDS are growing ever closer.
A JINGLE as the old lady enters. She surveys the scene as feasting on paradise. Maybe her eyes aren't so good.
Have a seat wherever you want, Ma'am. Specials are on the board.
Thank you, dear.
The old lady settles at a table across from the Andersons She smiles at them pleasantly. Charlie is about to hand her a menu, when:
Oh, I already know what I want.
Okay, what'll it be?
I'll have the steak, please.
And how'd you like that cooked?
Rare if you would. And water, no ice.
Coming right up.
Charlie, is it?
Yeah.
What an unusual name for a girl.
So they say. I'll be right back with your water.
The old lady turns to the Andersons.
Hello, I'm Gladys. Gladys Foster.
Nice to meet you, Gladys. I'm Sandra and this is my husband Howard.
What a nice young couple you are. What brings you out to these parts?
We're moving out to Scottsdale. But our truck broke down, and so we're stuck here while it's being fixed.
Oh, what a nuisance.
A FLY begins to buzz around Gladys's head.    She doesn't to notice it.
Say, Gladys, it seems the lines are down around here. The phone and TV, you know?
SANDRA (cont'd) And I just was wondering if you might have heard something on your way up? You know, about what's going on?
Gladys smiles strangely.
Oh, don't worry yourself about that, sweetheart. It'll all be over soon.

Sandra nods at the old woman, unsure of what to make of t response. The fly that was circling her head, now lands on GLADYS'S FACE. It crawls across her cheek without her reacting in least. Howard and Sandra exchange looks.    Creepy. The door JINGLES and Jeep walks in. He heads straight for quiet huddle with Bob. All the while though, he keeps one eye fixed on the old lady sitting at the table near the Andersons. Something about her...
The carburetor's shot.    Don't know why. Looks brand new.
(glances over at the
Ah, shit. They're gonna be pissed.
I could try to rebuild it, but it'd take a while, and I don't think we have all the parts. If we call right now, we might be able to get a new one down here tomorrow morning.
That's not gonna happen.    Goddamn phone's out.
What?
Across the diner, Charlie places a bloody red steak in fr of Gladys.
Thank you, dear. How far along are you?
Charlie rests a hand on her belly.
Just about there.
The father must be very proud.
I wouldn't know.
You mean he's...
Out of sight. Out of mind.
Oh, I see.     So you're not married, I take it?
A fly lands on Gladys's steak. Charlie tries to wave it away. But another one lands in its place.
Nope.
Gladys starts to dig in to the steak with a real ferociousness you wouldn't expect from an old lady.   Mor FLIES begin to land on her body. On her food. Charlie is still trying to wave them away.
That's too bad.
No, I prefer it that way. I don't a need a man tellin' me what to do.
But what about the baby?
I've got it under control.
Yeah, but it's gonna burn.
Charlie freezes. The Andersons turn to look as well.   Ky glances over from the counter.
What did you just say?
(all smiles) I said your fucking baby's gonna burn.
Charlie shakes her head at the woman, not giving in.
Go to hell, lady.
She slaps the check down on the table and walks back towa the kitchen, passing Jeep and Bob.
What happened?
Total fucking Jesus freak.

Gladys begins to laugh innocently as she continues to dev her meat. Red juice drips down her chin. The flies are swarming now. How did so many get in here? Sandra and Howard are mortified at this sudden turn of events.
All those babies.    They're gonna burn.
Gladys, please. There's no reason to --
Gladys's head suddenly whips toward her.
Shut up, you stupid fucking cunt! All you do is complain! Complain! Complain!
Sandra covers her mouth in shock.    Everybody in the din now focused on the old lady. Howard gets up from the booth.
Howard, it's okay!     Don't listen to her!
But Howard's already standing over Gladys.
Who the hell do you think you are, lady?! Now, I'd like you to apologize to my --

head_text.subj: GLADYS LUNGES AT HOWARD AND TAKES A MONSTROUS BITE OUT OF

text: EVERYBODY FREAKS as Howard crumbles to the floor. Gladys rockets to her feet, knocking her table over.   Bl covers her face and chest.
You're all going to fucking die!

Percy is the first to react. From behind the counter, he whips a heavy metal frying pan at Gladys that knocks her sideways. THWACK! BONES BREAK AND BURST FROM HER NECK.   Impossibly, Gladys still standing. She lets out an INHUMAN SCREAM and SCRAMBLES ACROSS THE DINER, knocking tables and chairs over in her wake. Bob pulls a shotgun from behind the counter.
Don't move!
But Gladys not only moves, SHE SCURRIES RIGHT UP THE FUCK

head_text.subj: WALL LIKE SOME KIND OF BIZARRE CRAB

text: Bob can't believe his eyes. But he gets over it real fast as the crab lady rushes toward him -- ACROSS THE CEILING
BOB PUMPS THE SHOTGUN, trying to take her down, but he ca track her fast enough. Instead he blows ENORMOUS HOLES in the ceiling, a rain of plaster. Gladys drops down right in front of Bob.
(struggles to cock the
Fuck!
Gladys smiles sweetly before SLAPPING HIM CLEAR ACROSS TH
The shotgun clatters to the floor at Jeep's feet. He snatches it up and aims it at Gladys who turns calmly to him.
Shoot her, Jeep!
Jeep's about to fire, when the old lady's EYES GO ALL WHI
(a sickly sweet smile) You'll never save her.
Jeep freezes, stunned by her words, overwhelming fear paralyzing him where he stands.
SHOOT THE FUCKING BITCH!
Gladys rockets straight at him! But Jeep's too afraid to move.    He clamps his eyes shut bracing himself for the end.

A RAIN OF BULLETS RIP INTO GLADYS, taking her down like a animal. Jeep slowly opens his eyes.   His gun's still cocked. Gladys lies dead in a smoldering, bloody heap at his feet He turns to see Kyle with smoke rising from the barrel of silver plated WESTERN ARMS 45. If everyone wasn't so shocked, they'd probably be wondering why this guy is pac such serious heat.
Somebody help me!
Sandra is on the floor with her husband.     Blood pours from his neck. Kyle stares at the dying man -- a moment of hesitation -- then he rushes to help.
Press your hands over the hole!
Sandra looks fearfully up at Kyle, at the gun still in hi hand.
Don't look at me like that, lady! I'm tryin' to fuckin' help you! Now put your goddamn hands over the hole before your husband bleeds to death!

Obeying, she cups her hands over the hole in his neck, desperately trying to stop the flow of blood leaking out between her fingers. Percy scrambles over with a first-ai kit and together he and Kyle get to work on Howard's neck
A few feet away, Charlie helps Bob, bruised and bleeding, his feet.
The fuck was that?!   What the fuck was that!?

Across the diner, Audrey is pushed back into a booth, her knees pulled tightly to her chest, shivering. Her adult facade giving way to that of a frightened child A DROP OF RED HITS AUDREY'S CHEEK, causing her to look up see Gladys's TRAIL OF BLOOD DRIPPING FROM THE CEILING. An ungodly horror.
Kyle, Percy, Sandra and Audrey frantically carry Howard, neck bandaged, to the back of the Escalade.
Howard lies in the back seat. Sandra by his head, claspin his hands in hers. Audrey by his feet. Percy rides shotgu Kyle struggles to get the key in the ignition. The engine ROARS to life.
The Escalade fishtails onto the highway.
Kyle grips the wheel.   Picking up speed.
How far to the hospital?
Seventy, maybe eighty miles.
Kyle shoots him a look. Eighty miles?! Pedal to the floor time. Audrey leans forward from the back seat.
What's that on the road?
Up ahead, the DARK CLOUDS Jeep saw earlier have finally closed in, descending onto the highway like a WALL.
They're fuckin' clouds!   What the fuck do they look like?
Not clouds. Clouds don't buzz.
She's right.    They're black... Undulating... BUZZING!
Suddenly HUNDREDS OF TINY BUGS begin to HIT the windshiel
And that's when they realize it... Those aren't clouds.

The Escalade enters the SWARM. The car is PUMMELED by insects, the windshield instantly covered in BLACK AND RE bug guts. Driving blind! The sound of FLIES SPLATTERING and BUZZING is deafening! Everyone SCREAMS as hell surrounds them...
Bob is hunched over the steaming sink, pounding a can of light beer. Jeep is leaning against the wall, looking lik he's about to puke or faint.
I don't understand how she was still standin' after Percy hit `er with that goddamn fryin' pan. Broke her fuckin' neck. I saw it. I swear I did.
And did you see that kid's gun? The hell's he doin' with a gun like that?
Bob looks over at Jeep, sees him trembling.
It's okay, Jeep.   It's okay.
But for Jeep it's not okay.   He's hurting real bad insid
I couldn't pull the trigger. I froze. I saw what I needed to do, but I was afraid... (breaks down) She could've killed you!
JEEP (cont'd) Or Charlie...She would've killed me if it wasn't for...
He can't get the words out.   Bob rests a hand on his boy shoulder.
There's nothin' to be ashamed of, Jeep. (BEAT) Not everybody can play the hero.
Before Jeep can respond, they hear the sound of the front DOOR JINGLE.
Bob and Jeep appear from the back, as Kyle, Percy, Audrey Sandra carry Howard into the diner, all of them stumbling gasping for air. Charlie moves in to help. Percy races for the back.
(catching Percy by the
Where you going?!
To get my bible!
The hell you need that for?!
Well somebody's gotta start prayin'...
Bob's about to respond when he hears the BUZZING. Bob, Charlie and Jeep slowly approach the windows to see
